goal_text: By (date), after the teacher reads a familiar biography at the student's reading level and gives the student two illustrations that each represent a key event in the book, (name) will orally answer a question (e.g., "Why was [character] doing this?") about the events in a single sentence that describes the two events using a conjunction (e.g., "for", "an", "but", "so", "nor", "or", "yet"), on (3) out of (4) questions.
objectives_objective_0_text:
By (date), after the teacher reads a familiar biography at student's reading level and given a question about why the central person made a decision or took an action, (name) will choose one illustration from the text to orally explain an action that the person took and why it happened (i.e., the cause and effect) in one sentence using a conjunction (i.e., because), on (3) out of (4) questions about the book.

Example:
1. Student and teacher read a biography together about Rosa Parks.
2. The teacher points to a picture and asks, "Why does Rosa Parks stay in her seat?"
3. The student should respond with a complete sentence, "Rosa Parks stays in her seat [because] she is tired."
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), given a [[ Sentence Starters | sentence frame ]] and two illustrations from two familiar biographies, (name) will orally answer the teacher's question about the similarities or differences between the two different people (e.g., creating compound sentences using and, but, so), on (3) out of (4) questions. 

Example Sentence frame: The __________ (man) is __________ (a soldier), (and, but) the  ____________ (son) is _________ (a teacher).
subject: English Learners
title: Combining Clauses in a Variety of Ways
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Before the teacher and the student read the texts together, the teacher can review examples of how to combine sentences from another familiar biography or informational text. (i.e., "Remember when we read this book? Listen to some examples of how to combine these two ideas from the story.") For the student who needs moderate support, the teacher could provide an example of how to compare two items. (i.e., "The first character is a woman, and the second character is a man.")
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text:
After the teacher asks the student a question, the teacher can supply sentence strips from the biography for the student to choose to combine. The sentence strips can be used to complete a sentence frame with a conjunction already in place.

Example: 
The ____is ____, (but) the ____ is ____.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: If the student seems shy about speaking or answering the question, give the student a choice of biographies, non-fiction texts and illustrations to talk about rather than teacher selected texts. This provides the student with the ability to make more of a connection with self-confidence and pride.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 7.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize individual choice and autonomy

goal_text: By (date), after given a partial script of a conversation that ends with an idiomatic phrase (e.g. "I am sick as a dog"), (name) will use the script to engage in a conversation with a peer and will continue the conversation off-script with dialog that shows understanding of the idiom (e.g. "Have you taken any medicine?") for (4 out of 5) conversations.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after listening to (5) sentences [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] and acted out by a [[ peer buddies | peer ]] in which figurative language is used, such as similes, (name) will complete the sentence orally by filling in the blank  (e.g. "She is as blind as a ___ (BAT)" ; "The man ___ (ROSE) from his seat") for (4 out of 5) sentences in (4 out of 5) vocabulary exercises.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date) after the teacher reads aloud a sentence that contains a homonym (e.g. "There are [two] books on the shelf "), (name) will point to the correct homonym from a [[ Multiple Choice | choice ]] of (2) flashcards each which has a picture and the word (e.g. "TO" or "TWO") for (3 out of 4) sentences in (4 out of 5) vocabulary exercises.

Sample Homonym Sentences:
* There are _____ books on the shelf, "TO" or "TWO"
* You inherit your _____ from your parents, "GENES" or JEANS"
* Her skin is very _____, "PAIL" or "PALE"
subject: English Learners
title: Understands Figurative Language and Words with Multiple Meanings
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Students who are acquiring a new language will find it helpful to use [[ picture choices | pictures ]] or videos in order to enhance understanding. In this case, the student will use flashcards that contain the words that he/she will select from. Additionally, if possible the flashcards may have a [[ picture choices | picture ]] that represents the word that he/she needs to select (e.g. Genes, Jeans).
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 1.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for visual information
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: When developing a new language, it is important to promote collaborative work amongst [[ peer buddies | peers ]]. Having a student that is more proficient in English [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] the sentences [[ http://englishlinx.com/idioms/Idioms-Meanings-P-1-Advanced.pdf | with idioms ]] to the English Learner, may significantly help build up confidence in his/her ability to respond. Also, it encourages the English Language Learner to make use of the language he/she has already acquired.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: The English Language Learner will greatly benefit from acquiring a new language through various modalities. In this case, he/she is listening to sentences being [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] to him/her as well as seeing [[ picture choices | picture choices ]]  or [[ multiple choice | multiple choices ]] to fill in the blanks in the sentences that were being presented.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL II 4.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Vary the methods for response and navigation

goal_text: By (date), provided two written narrative responses to a question (e.g. How is the importance of getting sleep related to academic success?), (name) will write a summary of the two responses that uses (2) sentences with an embedded clause (e.g. "The writer, newly graduated from UC Santa Cruz, explained her position clearly.") and (2) sentences using nominalization ("The writer's refusal to provide a counter argument lessened her credibility.") for (2 out of 3) sets of responses.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), provided two narrative responses in written and auditory formats (e.g. digital recording) to a question (e.g. How is the importance of getting sleep related to academic success?), and sentence starters related to the topic (e.g. "The first response ______" Both responses included information about______"  The second response was different from the first because______"), (name) will write a summary of the two responses that uses (3) sentences with multiple verbs and (2) sentences with an embedded clause (e.g. "The writer, newly graduated from UC Santa Cruz, explained her position clearly.") for (2 out of 3) sets of responses.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), provided two narrative responses in written and auditory formats (e.g. digital recording) to a question (e.g. How is the importance of getting sleep related to academic success?), (name) will write (1) compound sentence that explains the main idea of each response using linking words (e.g. "and", "but", "or" "The first author felt sleep was important [but] the second author did not.")  for (2 out of 3) sets of responses.
subject: English Learners
title: Condensing information
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Providing students with pre-made sentence starters to analyze the information given from the question ("How is the importance of getting sleep related to academic success?") will not only allow access for students with lower language skills, but also for students who have anxiety about initiating work. Sentence starters allow students to synthesize the information even if they struggle to write complete sentences independently.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: In this goal, students are working on learning the difference between a variety of complexity in sentences. For students who are proficient readers but have lower skills in the area of writing, providing a teacher made list of sentences to choose from will allow them to analyze the material by focusing on their language skills. Accommodating students' needs in this way minimizes the threat of this activity and also gets at the core purpose of this goal by starting students off with the simplified task of identifying the sentence with the action word, or verb.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL III 7.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Minimize threats and distractions
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Providing students with the written and recorded formats of the responses they are to synthesize allows for students who are stronger in listening or reading to access the material. Allowing them the choice to listen to the information as well as read it is ideal as students will acquire the skills needed to access the information the more they see and hear the information.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL I 1.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Offer alternatives for auditory information

goal_text:
By (date), after viewing a series of (6-8) scenes depicting humorous mistakes (e.g. a student getting up early and racing to get to school on time, only to find out it's Saturday) and clarifying the content of the images in a [[guided peer discussions|class discussion]], (name) will use at least (2) different types of verb tenses to write (1) complex sentence for each image that explains the mistake shown and will check his/her work with a partner by taking turns reading their sentences aloud and making necessary revisions to their writing and speech for (6 out of 8) sentences for (2 out of 3) writing exercises.

Example of a complex sentence:  "He thought he had to rush to school, but he realized it was Saturday."
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after viewing a series of (6-8) scenes depicting humorous mistakes (e.g. a student getting up early and racing to get to school on time, only to find out it's Saturday) and clarifying the content of the images in a [[guided peer discussions|class discussion]], (student) will use at least (2) different types of verb tenses to complete (1) teacher-created [[Sentence Starters|sentence frame]] for each image that explains the mistake shown in the picture and will check his/her work with a partner by taking turns reading their sentences aloud and making necessary revisions to their writing and speech for (6 out of 8) sentences for (2 out of 3) writing exercises.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after viewing a series of (6-8) images depicting common daily tasks (e.g. riding a bike, going to the store, cooking dinner, reading a book, etc.) marked with dates/times in the past, present, and future, and clarifying the content of the images in a [[guided peer discussions|class discussion]] (student) will reference his/her [[Vocabulary Journal|vocabulary journal]] to find at least (2) different types of verb tenses which help him/her write (1) sentence for each image that narrates the task shown in the picture in the appropriate verb tense and will check his/her work with a partner by taking turns reading their sentences aloud and making necessary revisions to their writing and speech for (6 out of 8) sentences for (2 out of 3) writing exercises.
subject: English Learners
title: Conjugating Verbs Across Tenses
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Instead of students relying on memory to determine appropriate verbs and verb tenses, teachers can facilitate the use of [[Vocabulary Journal|vocabulary journals]], in which students keep track of new words and usages. Students may reference these journals during their writing to assist with memory, spelling, meaning, and conjugation, and can add to these journals throughout their lessons when a new word or concept is introduced.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Instead of students writing sentences independently, which could result in simpler language used than desired, teachers can provide [[Sentence Starters|sentence frames]], which guide students to use more expressive verbs across different tenses. Providing sentence frames also helps focus the students' thinking on the objective (selecting and conjugating verbs) so that students don't get distracted by other vocabulary obstacles.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Instead of students working in partners to practice reading their sentences, teachers can gather the class for [[Choral Reading|choral reading]] of students' sentences at the end of the activity. This creates incentive for students to complete their work and write high-quality sentences because they'll be shared with the class, and allows for the teacher to monitor students' pronunciation of verbs, serving as a formative assessment of students' speaking skills.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 9.1 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Promote expectations and beliefs that optimize motivation

goal_text:
By (date), when given an introductory paragraph of a narrative, (student) will identify the verb (a word or group of words that sometimes convey action but always show "time" of past, present, or future) and the subject of the verb (a word or group of words that identify something doing the action of the verb) in each sentence, and write a second (3-5 sentence) paragraph to continue the narrative, including at least (3) verbs with correct tense (simple past), and (3) subjects in correct agreement with the verb.

Guidelines for Verb Tense and Subject-Verb Agreement
1. Two of the verb tenses in the English language are simple present (I study) and simple past (I studied). 
2. To identify the subject of the verb, first identify the verb itself. Example: Jane planned a party for her best friend.
Identify the verb: "planned."
Ask, "who or what "planned"? The answer is Jane. So, Jane is the subject of the verb: Jane planned. 
3. Singular subjects (e.g.  "I," "you," "he," "she," "it," "each," "every," "woman") need singular verbs and plural subjects (e.g. "we," "you," "they," "employees") need plural verbs. 

Example paragraph (10 sentences):

Yesterday, I bought tea in the coffee shop near my house (verb is "bought," subject is "I"). The pastry case was full (verb is "was," subject is "pastry case"). Two customers laughed out loud (verb is "laughed," subject is "two customers"). They drank hot chocolate merrily (verb is "drank," subject is "they"). The employee rang the order on the cash register (verb is "rang," subject is "the employee"). Another employee offered help (verb is "offered," subject is "another employee"). A third employee prepared the tea and a cup of coffee (verb is "prepared," subject is "a third employee"). A man nearby told a joke (verb is "told," subject is "a man nearby"). A woman in a red coat opened the door (verb is "opened," subject is "a woman"). The wind blew briskly (verb is "blew," subject is "the wind").

title: Identifying and Writing Verbs and Subjects of Verbs
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text:
Providing students with the opportunity to edit a partner's work gives them an opportunity for one-on-one support and collaboration with a peer. Provide them a list of things to look for as they [[ Peer Tutoring | peer edit ]] their partner's paragraph or sentence. Ask them to provide feedback either by writing down or marking the piece to indicate where errors exist. Then ask the students to discuss the edits with their peer:
1. Identify the verb in each sentence. Does it show "past" time or action?
2. Identify the subject of the verb in each sentence. Does the subject you identified answer the question of "who or what" is doing the "action" of the verb? Does it agree with the singular or plural verb?

udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: A [[ Vocabulary Journal | vocabulary journal ]] is a flexible tool that students can use to reinforce their learning and understanding of familiar and new vocabulary. In this task, students make their own list of unfamiliar words to enter into the journal. The students can be asked to define the words, illustrate the words, or provide an example of the words in context, or any combination of these. When students share their lists with one another, encourage them to work together to discuss the definitions and check each others' work. This collaborative process can provide support, motivation, and engagement in the task of learning new vocabulary.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 6.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Facilitate managing information and resources
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: The [[ Highlighting | highlighting ]] of the verb and subject of the verb in each of the sentences provides a scaffolding that removes the need for the student to first select from an entire sentence which word or groups of words is the verb and the subject of the verb.  Thus, students can better focus on, think about, and learn the goal of this task,  which is to identify the verb and the subject of the verb.

udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Rather than providing students with plain text, teachers can help students gain an understanding of when to use English conventions by providing them with an [[ adapted text | adapted version ]] of the text.  Often, illustrations can be helpful when students are attempting to gain an understanding of both what the text says, and when conventions should be used.  Therefore, teachers can find illustrated passages to help those students that are struggling with standard conventions, or who need extra help with text.

objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after [[ Pre-Reading | previewing ]] an instructional level short story where the teacher will highlight any illustrations and text features and [[ Read Aloud | listening to ]] the story read aloud (3) times, (name) will create a [[ Poster Summary | summary poster ]] which includes at least one illustration or image for each of the following story elements: 1) major character(s), 2) theme and 3) significant plot event(s) for (2 out 3) stories.

title: Elements of a Short Story
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: When working with text that is distinct from one’s native language, it can be easy for learners to focus on barriers to fluent comprehension. A teacher can combat students’ fears and reservations by encouraging learners to focus on their strengths, emphasizing what they already know, and highlighting potential challenges in advance. Prior to reading aloud short stories, teachers can use [[ Pre-Reading | pre-reading ]] to pull out aspects of the story that he or she anticipates may cause confusion. This may mean defining certain vocabulary in advance, or highlighting text features or illustrations. Confronting challenges in advance of hearing the story aloud may give students the confidence and tools to further comprehend short stories.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Detailing story elements orally or in writing may prove challenging to learners focused on developing language proficiency. Providing students with the option of summarizing their understanding of short stories through a [[ Poster Summary | summary poster ]] may reduce barriers and empower students to display deeper levels of mastery.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: In addition to being written in English, short stories often take place in a time and setting that is very distinct from students' modern lives. Working with so many points of difference may make it difficult for some learners to fully engage in comprehending short stories. In order to generate student excitement, teachers may choose to integrate a student's personal interests when selecting a short story to share. For instance, if a student has expressed interest in scary stories the teacher could work with the student to select a short story by Edgar Allan Poe. Or, the teacher could seek out short stories in which the main character possess similarities to the learner. Incorporating student interest may serve to add familiarity and interest to short stories.

title: Elements of a Short Story
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: When working with text that is distinct from one’s native language, it can be easy for learners to focus on barriers to fluent comprehension. A teacher can combat students’ fears and reservations by encouraging learners to focus on their strengths, emphasizing what they already know, and highlighting potential challenges in advance. Prior to reading aloud short stories, teachers can use [[ Pre-Reading | pre-reading ]] to pull out aspects of the story that he or she anticipates may cause confusion. This may mean defining certain vocabulary in advance, or highlighting text features or illustrations. Confronting challenges in advance of hearing the story aloud may give students the confidence and tools to further comprehend short stories.

udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Detailing story elements orally or in writing may prove challenging to learners focused on developing language proficiency. Providing students with the option of summarizing their understanding of short stories through a [[ Poster Summary | summary poster ]] may reduce barriers and empower students to display deeper levels of mastery.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: In addition to being written in English, short stories often take place in a time and setting that is very distinct from students' modern lives. Working with so many points of difference may make it difficult for some learners to fully engage in comprehending short stories. In order to generate student excitement, teachers may choose to integrate a student's personal interests when selecting a short story to share. For instance, if a student has expressed interest in scary stories the teacher could work with the student to select a short story by Edgar Allan Poe. Or, the teacher could seek out short stories in which the main character possess similarities to the learner. Incorporating student interest may serve to add familiarity and interest to short stories.

goal_text:
By (date), after completing the prewriting, drafting, and revising steps of the 5-Step Writing Process and being given a [[ Glossary | cheat-sheet ]] of standard editing marks, (name) will edit a (1-4) page piece of writing on a self-selected topic using a dictionary and [[ writing checklist | an editing checklist ]] to self-edit for misspelled words, punctuation, capitalization, subject/verb agreement, catching (75-80%) of the errors in the piece. (Name) will then exchange papers with a partner to check each other's work for additional errors, and create a corrected second draft to be attached to the original.

5-STEP PROCESS WRITING:
1. Prewriting- choose a topic and brainstorm ideas, pictures, details, etc. so you don't get stuck while writing
2. Drafting- organize your thoughts on paper, focus on content not mechanics
3. Revising- add, delete, or change information to make the writing sound the way you want it to, focus is still on content
4. Editing- fix errors in spelling, punctuation, capitalization, grammar, and sentence structure
5. Publishing- share the final draft by making it into a book, hanging it on the wall, or reading it aloud to the class

goal_text:
By (date), after the student has created a 3-D shape with (10) inch cubes of different colors, (name) will give a peer at least (10) verbal directions (using complete sentences) to recreate the shape hidden from the peer's view which include at least (1) sentence with a prepositional phrase (e.g., on top off, to the left of, by the red cube), (1) sentence with an adverb phrase (e.g., very slowly), and (1) sentence with an adverb (e.g., slowly, close, high) on (3) out of (4) shape creations.

Example Sequence of Instruction:
1. The student will create a 3 dimensional shape with 10 one inch cubes and keep it hidden from a peer. 
2. The student will use complete sentences that include prepositional phrases, adverbial phrases, and an adverb to help the peer to recreate the object. (e.g., "Put the blue cube in the center. Very carefully place a red cube on top of the blue cube. Place a yellow cube to the right  touching the blue cube.")
3. Students then show each other their shapes. If they are exactly the same, the directions were very clear.
objectives_objective_0_text:
By (date), after the student has created a 3-D shape with (8) inch cubes of different colors and given visual cue cards of adverbial phrases (e.g. [picture of arrow pointing to top of cube] => "on top of"), (name) will give a peer at least (8) verbal directions to recreate the shape that is hidden from the peer's view that includes at least (1) complete sentence that uses a prepositional phrase (e.g., on top off, to the left of, by the red cube), an adverb phrase (e.g., very slowly), or an adverb (e.g., slowly, close, high) for (3) out of (4) shape creations.

Example:
1. The student will create a 3 dimensional shape with 8 one inch cubes of multiple colors and keep it hidden from a peer. 
2. The teacher can give visual cue cards that prompt the student to use a prepositional phrase or adverb (e.g., picture of a cube with an arrow pointing to the top of it = "on top of," versus "at the top of", "slowly" has a yield sign).
3. The student will use at least one of the three types of adverbial phrases to expand their sentences while giving directions.
4. Students then show each other their shapes. If they are exactly the same, the directions were very clear.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), after the student has created a 3-D shape with (4) inch cubes of different colors and after developing the first (3 out of 4) instructions in writing with the teacher's assistance through [[ Interactive Writing | interactive writing ]], (name) will read aloud each instruction to a peer to recreate the shape that is hidden from the peer's view and independently create the fourth (and final) instruction that includes a prepositional phrase (e.g., on top off, to the left of, by the red cube) or an adverb (e.g., slowly, close, high) for (3) out of (4) shape creations.

Example:
1. The student will create a 3 dimensional shape with 4 one inch cubes of multiple colors and keep it hidden from a peer. 
2. The student will give directions to the peer to recreate the 3-D shape exactly as the student's original shape. 
3. If the student is having trouble, the teacher can give visual cue cards that prompts the student to use a prepositional phrase or adverb (e.g., picture of a cube with an arrow pointing to the top of it = "on top of").
4. The student will use prepositions or adverbs to expand their sentences while giving directions. (e.g., "Place the blue cube high on the red cube.")

goal_text:
By (date), after the student has created a 3-D shape with (10) inch cubes of different colors, (name) will give a peer at least (10) verbal directions (using complete sentences) to recreate the shape hidden from the peer's view which include at least (1) sentence with a prepositional phrase (e.g., on top off, to the left of, by the red cube), (1) sentence with an adverb phrase (e.g., very slowly), and (1) sentence with an adverb (e.g., slowly, close, high) on (3) out of (4) shape creations.

Example Sequence of Instruction:
1. The student will create a 3 dimensional shape with 10 one inch cubes and keep it hidden from a peer. 
2. The student will use complete sentences that include prepositional phrases, adverbial phrases, and an adverb to help the peer to recreate the object. (e.g., "Put the blue cube in the center. Very carefully place a red cube on top of the blue cube. Place a yellow cube to the right  touching the blue cube.")
3. Students then show each other their shapes. If they are exactly the same, the directions were very clear.

objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), when asked to state and defend a personal opinion about a controversial topic (e.g. school dress code), after brainstorming collaboratively with peers, (name) will complete a graphic organizer selecting: (2) reasons to support his/her claims, (2) specific pieces of evidence related to the reasons and join those brainstormed ideas cohesively by using (3) transitional words (e.g. "meanwhile", "moreover", or "on the other hand") and use the graphic organizer to independently draft an essay for (3) out of (4) persuasive essay topics.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date) after listening to a short story [[ Read Aloud | read aloud ]] in class by his/her teacher, (name) will retell the story by completing a [[ Picture Story Telling | picture story telling ]] sequence and label each box with a transition word (e.g. "First" on the top left box; "Then" on the top right box; "Next" on the bottom left box; and "Finally" on the bottom right box), he/she must write a short sentence that describes the picture in each box and orally share with peers his/her picture sequence for (3) out of (4) stories.

goal_text: By (date), after pre-teaching definitions for and examples of prepositions, prepositional phrases, and adverbs, and going on a nature walk, (student) will write and read aloud (to a partner, group, or the class) a (300-500 word) journal entry to describe the observations (sight, smell, hearing, touch) made during the nature walk from another organism's perspective (e.g. an insect's perspective, a squirrel's perspective, a bird's perspective), using at least (5) prepositional phrases and (5) adverbs to expand the observations and add interest to the writing (e.g. A squirrel munched loudly on a nut: "loudly" is the adverb and "on a nut" is the prepositional phrase).
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after pre-teaching definitions for and examples of prepositions, prepositional phrases, and adverbs, and going on a nature walk, (student) will use a [[ Word Bank | word bank ]] of prepositions to write and read aloud (to a partner, group, or the class) a (300-500 word) journal entry to describe his/her own observations (sight, smell, hearing, touch) made during the nature walk, using at least (5) prepositional phrases and (5) adverbs to expand the observations and add interest to the writing.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), after pre-teaching definitions for and examples of prepositions, prepositional phrases, and adverbs entered into a [[ Vocabulary Journal | vocabulary journal ]], and going on a nature walk, when given (10) [[ Sentence Starters | pre-written sentences ]] of observations from one spot in a natural area that are missing either prepositional phrases or adverbs, (student) will use the vocabulary journal and a list of adverbs and prepositional phrases to choose from to write the prepositional phrases and adverbs for the sentences, and read the sentences aloud (to a partner, group, or the class).

Example sentences:
1. The sun was shining ________ on the tree ("brightly") [missing an adverb]. 
2. An insect walked quickly __________ ("on the branch") [missing a prepositional phrase]. 

Example list of adverbs and prepositional phrases:
brightly
quietly
hurriedly
in the bush
on the sidewalk
over the stream
subject: English Learners
title: Using Prepositional Phrases and Adverbs to Expand Writing and Speaking
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: For this task, pre-teaching the definitions of prepositions, prepositional phrases, and adverbs will provide all students structured access to these sentence elements prior to using them in their writing. Once you give students definitions and examples, ask them to come up with their own examples to share in a discussion. You might want to ask for examples that pertain to the specific experience they will be writing about. You might also emphasize, using the example sentence "A squirrel munched loudly on a nut," that the writing becomes more interesting when the adverb (loudly) and the prepositional phrase (on a nut) are added, versus a sentence without those elements ("A squirrel munched").

udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: For this task, after pre-teaching the definitions for and examples of prepositions, prepositional phrases, and adverbs, ask students to prepare a vocabulary journal to reinforce their learning of the definitions. You may give them a choice of writing the definitions in their own words and/or drawing a picture of examples of each. By completing a vocabulary journal, students are engaged in and empowered by their own learning. Students can then use the vocabulary journal as a relevant tool for reference while they are writing the journal entry about the nature observation.

goal_text:
By (date), after participating in a [[ read aloud | read aloud ]] of a picture book with rich descriptive detail (e.g. Owl Moon by Jane Yolen) and identifying descriptive sentences from the text as a class, (name) will write a (3-5) paragraph descriptive piece on a student-selected topic containing (4-6) complex sentences with embedded (subordinate) clauses and (2-4) compound sentences.

SAMPLE DESCRIPTIVE SENTENCES (FROM OWL MOON):
The trees stood STILL as GIANT statues.
We reached the line of pine trees, BLACK and POINTY against the sky.
My mouth felt FURRY, for the scarf over it was WET and WARM.
The kind of hope that flies on SILENT wings under a SHINING Owl Moon. 

COMPOUND SENTENCES have two or more independent clauses joined with a coordinating conjunction.
FOR EXAMPLE: I wanted to climb to the top of the beautiful waterfall, but the rocks looked slippery and dangerous.

COMPLEX SENTENCES have one independent clause and one or more subordinate (embedded or dependent) clause.
FOR EXAMPLE: While gazing at the lovely waterfall, I saw a bright ray of sunlight dance across the clear surface.

Compare and contrast school today with school during the Civil War Era.

goal_text:
By (date), after choosing from a list of foreign countries provided by his/her teacher, (name) will write a persuasive essay to convince his/her classmates why his/her country is the best place to live in the world, incorporating (2) complex embedded clauses and (5) adjectives, per paragraph, for (4 out of 5) paragraphs for (3 out of 4) writing exercises.

Complex Embedded Clause: 
Two or more independent clauses with one or more dependent clause(s) joined by subordinating conjunctions such as: "because", "and", "although", used to explain time, place, reason, or other conditions in which an action took place.

Example of a Complex Embedded Clause: 
“Argentina is the ideal place to live in the world because of it’s vast open space, magnificent food, pristine beaches, and rich history.”

title: Using Key Math Vocabulary to Problem Solve
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: At this level, word problems rarely give students explicit directions for how to solve the problem. Rather, learners must interpret the language within the problem in order to determine their next steps. Key language can be even more difficult to identify outside of one’s first language. Therefore, teachers can assist English language learners by providing a [[ Reference Materials | key language glossary ]] which provides students with words or phrases that signal mathematical operations. Such a tool can help students identify, prioritize and make sense of key language that might not otherwise stand out.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Using key language to solve mathematical problems involves multiple steps for all learners. Students must read the problem, identify key language, interpret the language to determine what the problem is asking, correctly utilize the information to set up an inequality, and finally solve the problem. English language learners experience the added layer of making sense of mathematical problems outside of their first language. Any learner could get lost in the multiple steps. In order to assist English language learners in navigating the many steps, teachers can provide a [[ Problem Solving Checklist | problem solving checklist ]].  Offering a tool to guide learners through each single step can prevent confusion and lead to mastery of this important and complex skill.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 6.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Support planning and strategy development
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: As this goal requires students to engage in complex problem solving, it is important to help keep students engaged and help them recognize their own progress. In order to help students celebrate small wins, teachers can utilize a [[ Vocabulary Knowledge Rating Sheet | vocabulary knowledge rating sheet ]]. Teachers can introduce key language at the beginning of the lesson or unit and offer checkpoints throughout the learning process for students to monitor and assess their familiarity with the language.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 9.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Develop self-assessment and reflection

goal_text:
By (date), after self-selecting a current event topic (e.g. politics, health care, the environment, or popular culture) and given a set of guiding questions that require the student's personal opinion beyond summarization and factual recall (e.g. "What new information did you learn?", "Who would you recommend this website or video to and why?"), (name) will give a (3-5) minute long oral presentation summarizing the topic, present (2-3) websites, Youtube videos, or other online sources  supporting the topic, as well as addressing at least (4) of the guiding personal reflection questions.

SAMPLE GUIDING QUESTIONS:
* What is your overall opinion of the topic? 
* Who created the website or video? 
* Who is the target audience of the website or video? 
* Do you agree or disagree with the information presented? Why or why not?
* What new information did you learn? 
* Who would you recommend this website or video to and why?
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after self-selecting a current event topic (e.g. politics, health care, the environment, or popular culture), (name) will give a (2-4) minute long oral presentation summarizing the topic, present (1-2) websites, Youtube videos, or other online sources supporting the topic, as well as stating his/her opinion of the online sources and the topic in general.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), after previewing and selecting one of three teacher-presented [[ Video | Youtube videos ]] on a current event topic (e.g. politics, health care, the environment, or popular culture), (name) will paraphrase the information in the video by first practicing his/her presentation one-on-one with preferred peer(s) before presenting to the teacher in a one-on-one setting, using (3-4) complete sentences and (3-4) topic-specific vocabulary words in their final presentation.

EXAMPLES OF TOPIC SPECIFIC VOCABULARY:
THE ENVIRONMENT: global warming, climate change, ecosystem, carbon footprint
HEALTHCARE: insurance, copay, premium, benefits, treatment
POPULAR CULTURE: celebrity, meme, social media
subject: English Learners
title: Interpreting Information from Multimedia Sources
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Allowing the student to support the presentation with visual sources such as videos and websites containing both pictures and texts, rather than solely with text, scaffolds language development and content comprehension.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Allowing the students to choose both a topic and source material for the presentation that is both current and relevant to their interests will increase the authenticity of the project as well as enhancing student engagement.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Allowing beginning English speakers multiple opportunities to present information to peers and the teacher in one-on-one settings will help them build confidence and fluency that can build up to a whole-class oral presentation if and when they are ready.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance

goal_text:
By (date), after a student has solved a math word problem in a math notebook and after the teacher asks the student questions to discuss the problem to elicit past, future and present verb tenses, (name) will answer three questions using 3 different tenses with respect to the question being asked, on (2) out of (3) questions. 

Example Questions:
1. To elicit use of past tense verbs: 
Teacher:  Look back at the work you did to solve the problem. What steps did you take to solve the problem?
Student: First I (read) the question. Then I (added) the two numbers. I (went) over the work and (checked) it.
2. To elicit use of future tense verbs: 
Teacher: If you were to solve this problem again or one like it, what would you do differently next time?
Student:  I (would) use a calculator to check my work next time. I (could) also ask a friend for help.
3. To elicit use of the present tense verbs: 
Teacher: Do you like math? Why or why not? What do you like about math and solving problems?
Student: I (like) math. It (is) fun to solve problems with my friends.
objectives_objective_0_text:
By (date), after a student has solved a math word problem in a math notebook and after the teacher has modeled using verb tenses through a discussion with the student about the solution to the problem, (name) will answer three questions using 2 different tenses (e.g present and past) with respect to the question being asked, on (2) out of (3) questions. 

Example Discussion Questions:
1. To elicit use of past tense verbs: 
Teacher: Let's talk about how you solved this problem. (Student and teacher discuss together with teacher modeling correct verb tense.) Now can you tell me what steps did you take to solve the problem? 
2. To elicit use of the present tense verbs: 
Teacher: Do you like math? Why or Why not? or What do you like about math and solving problems?
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), after a student has solved a math word problem in a math notebook and after the teacher has modeled using the simple past verb tense, (name) will use a [[ word bank | word bank ]] from a [[ graphic organizers | graphic organizer ]] with past tense verb illustrations to answer three questions guided by the teacher using the simple past verb tense, on (2) out of (3) questions. 

Example Discussion Questions:
Teacher: Let's talk about how you solved this problem. Now can you tell me what steps did you take to solve the problem? What did you like best about you work? What did you like best about the problem?
subject: English Learners
title: Use a Wide Variety of Verb Tenses While Speaking
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Teachers can use a [[ graphic organizers | concept graphic organizer ]] with a familiar illustration of past, present and future with frequently used subjects and verbs attached to that illustration. An illustration for the present tense might be one of the classroom they are in at the moment with simple sentences such as, "I am" "I like" "Math is". They can be set up as sentence starters to help prompt the discussion about the math problem the student and the teacher discuss.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text:
Teachers can provide [[ sentence starters | sentence starters ]] to help the student during the discussion of the math problem. 

Example:
I like math because (I like measuring things).
I used addition because (it helped me add two things together).

udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Instead of students having to discuss a particular problem the teacher wants him/her to explain, the teacher can give the student a choice from a variety of problems to discuss. Choice ensures that the student feels more confident and comfortable discussing problems with the teacher.

goal_text:
By (date), when shown an illustration of a main character (e.g. Jasper) from a familiar story (e.g. [[ http://www.amazon.com/Creepy-Carrots-Aaron-Reynolds/dp/1442402970 | Creepy Carrots ]] by Aaron Reynolds) and asked to describe the main character in the illustration, (name) will write at least (3) descriptive sentences about the character using at least (1) adjective, for (3 out of 4) writing activities.

Example Response:
Jasper eats carrots. He eats them from the ground. He is scared and thinks they are following him. So, Jasper builds a wall around the carrots.

goal_text:
By (date), when revising a draft of his or her own writing, (name) will improve the draft by adding at least (3) transitional or linking words in (2 out of 3) writing activities.

Sample Student Draft:
My mom doesn't like pizza.  We don't eat it very often.

Sample Student Revision:
My mom doesn't like pizza, therefore we don't eat it very often.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), when revising a draft of his or her own writing, (name) will [[ highlighting | highlight ]] at least (3) places where transitional words could be added to improve their writing, and then correctly select an appropriate transitional word to use from a [[ word bank | word bank ]] in (2 out of 3) writing activities.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), when given a draft of his or her own writing that has been edited and marked by the teacher, (name) will fill in appropriate transition words in at least (3) specific locations identified by the teacher in the draft for (2 out of 3) writing activities.

Sample Student Draft:
I don't like to go home. [Teacher editing mark between sentences] All my friends are still playing.

Sample Student Revision:
I don't like to go home because all of my friends are still playing.
subject: English Learners
title: Revising Drafted Writing
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: When students are trying to find places that they can revise, they can use [[highlighting | highlighters]] to go through their drafts and mark where they should include transitional words.  This will help them practice identifying weaker parts of their writing, and allow them to strengthen their work.  This skill can also be used for other forms of revising, and is definitely not limited to transitional words.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.2 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Highlight patterns, critical features, big ideas, and relationships
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Students can have access to a [[word bank | word bank]] that includes examples of common transitional words.  Rather than having students come up with these words on their own, they can use this tool to make their writing as strong as possible.  Word banks are great for students who are still developing mastery of the English language because they provide these students with a number of appropriate words.  Word banks can always be tailored to the individual student's language and writing levels.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.2 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple tools for construction and composition
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Students can help one another find places to revise with [[peer tutoring | peer editing]].  If a student is particularly good at revising their draft to include more transitional words, that student can help others who are struggling with the same task.  By practicing with their peers, students may gain confidence in their ability to revise their writing, and find that they are capable of performing the revisions on their own.

goal_text: By (date), after reading a grade-level informational text about a topic from science class, (name) will give a (2) minute oral presentation that includes (5) important facts and details about the topic using at least (5) complete sentences about the informational text in (3 out of 4) oral presentations.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after watching a grade level [[ video | informational video ]] about a topic in science class and after the class takes class notes together about the topic, (name) will participate in class discussions about what was presented in the video by orally contributing at least (3) connections to the topic using complete sentences, in (3 out of 4) class discussions.
objectives_objective_1_text:
By (date), after watching a grade level [[video|informational video]] about a topic in science class and after the class takes [[http://www.stepupresources.co.nz/images/cloze.jpg|cloze notes]] (e.g. by completing sentence frames together), (name) will repeat (3) facts the class learned from the video, during (3 out of 4) class discussions.

Example Class Notes and Sentence Frames:
(If topic is on the life cycle of the frog.)
1. The ___ (frog) lives in the ____(rain forest). 
2. The (frog) is first an (egg).
3. The (egg) hatches and is a (tadpole).
4. The (legs) begin to (sprout).
5. A (young frog) will leave the (water) to mate again.

title: Give Oral Presentations on Content Based Topics
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Teachers can provide students with a note-taking [[ graphic organizers | graphic organizer ]] to help the student manage new information for his/her presentation. title: Use Nouns and Noun Phrases
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Consider using picture supports for word banks as a way of providing access for non-independent readers, and as as a way of strengthening meaning for ELL students. goal_text:
By (date), after performing a grade-level science experiment (e.g. in science class), and given an overview of the definition of a verb and verb tenses [[ Preteaching | taught ]] immediately before given the lab report task, (student) will complete the following categories of a lab report: describe the procedure, explain the findings of the experiment, and discusses one idea for a next step to take if the experiment were to be performed again by writing (500-700) words containing at least (2) verbs in past tense, (2) in present tense, and (2) in future tense for (2 out of 3) lab reports.

Example sentences with verbs in each tense:
Present tense: Boil the water on a hot plate (boil).
Past tense: We found that the color did not change (found, did not).
Future tense: In a future experiment, it will be useful to boil the water at various temperatures instead of one temperature (will be).
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after performing a grade-level science experiment (e.g. in science class), and given an overview of the definition of a verb and verb tenses [[ Preteaching | taught ]] immediately before given the lab report task, (student) will use a [[ Writing Checklist | writing checklist ]] to complete the following categories of a lab report: describe the procedure, explain the findings of the experiment, and discusses one idea for a next step to take if the experiment were to be performed again by writing (500-700) words containing at least (2) verbs in past tense and (2) in future tense for (2 out of 3) lab reports.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after performing a grade-level science experiment (e.g. in science class), and given an overview of the definition of a verb and verb tenses [[ Preteaching | taught ]] immediately before given the lab report task, and given a pre-written informational lab report that describes the procedure (present tense) and explains the findings of the experiment (past tense, (student) will read the lab report with a [[ Partner Reading | partner ]], make a list of 80% or more of the verbs, record the tense of each verb (past or present), and write two sentences containing verbs in the proper tense to add to the experimental findings for (2 out of 3) lab reports.
subject: English Learners
title: Using Verbs and Verb Phrases
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: For this task, [[ Preteaching | holding a discussion ]] with students can activate their prior knowledge of verbs and verb tenses (past, present, and future) so they can be successful in writing their own sentences containing verbs for the lab report. If necessary, you can provide a definition of a verb ( a word or group of words that show action or time of past, present, or future), and examples of verbs in each of the tenses. You can then ask students to pair up and come up with their own examples of verbs in each tense to share with the class.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text:
Providing students with a [[ Writing Checklist | writing checklist ]] can help them monitor their progress in writing the lab report, and check to see that they have included all of the requirements for verbs and verb tenses.

Example Writing Checklist:
1. Name
2. Date
3. Title of experiment
4. Explanation of experimental findings
a. At least (4) verbs in past tense
5. Discussion of one idea for a next step in a future experiment
a. At least (2) verbs in future tense
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 6.4 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Enhance capacity for monitoring progress
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: For this task, giving students the opportunity to read the pre-written lab report with a [[ Partner Reading | partner ]] provides one-on-one peer support for and engagement in learning the verbs and verb tenses. If necessary, you can provide a definition of a verb ( a word or group of words that show action or time of past, present, or future), and examples of verbs in each of the tenses. You can then ask students to pair up and come up with their own examples of verbs in each tense to share with the class.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.1 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Activate or supply background knowledge
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text:
Providing students with a [[ Writing Checklist | writing checklist ]] can help them monitor their progress in writing the lab report, and check to see that they have included all of the requirements for verbs and verb tenses.

Example Writing Checklist:
1. Name
2. Date
3. Title of experiment
4. Explanation of experimental findings
a. At least (4) verbs in past tense
5. Discussion of one idea for a next step in a future experiment
a. At least (2) verbs in future tense
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 6.4 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Enhance capacity for monitoring progress
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: For this task, giving students the opportunity to read the pre-written lab report with a [[ Partner Reading | partner ]] provides one-on-one peer support for and engagement in learning the verbs and verb tenses. It can also support motivation to write their own sentences to add to the lab report.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication

goal_text: By (date), after independently reading a grade level passage containing at least (10) figures of speech, (name) will select (5) of the figures of speech and write an original definition correctly interpreting the meaning for (4 out of 5) of the selections.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after given a visually supported instructional level passage containing multiple figures of speech, and (5) definitions aligned to figures of speech within the passage, (name) will [[ Read Aloud | listen to ]] and read along with the passage 2-3 times and then circle the figures of speech within the passage and draw a line to the corresponding definition correctly for (4 out of 5) of the figures of speech.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after given (10) sentences that have metaphors or similes with corresponding illustrations, (name) will identify the two things being compared by underlining them ("The [boy] ran as fast as a [cheetah]." and circle the words or phrases used to compare them (e.g. "as fast as") for (8 out of 10) sentences.
subject: English Learners
title: Understanding Figurative Language
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: As learners of a new language are often translating based on the context of their native tongues, accessing figurative language can be especially challenging. Providing students with a figurative language [[ Reference Materials | glossary ]], or encouraging them to make their own, could provide support for memory and transfer and ultimately lead to stronger mastery.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.4 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Maximize transfer and generalization
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: As an alternative to creating an original definition for a given figure of speech, a teacher could offer students the option of providing interpretations through [[ Illustration | illustrations ]]. The concept of figurative language is a sophisticated concept for all learners, and offering this alternative may enable English language learners to more deeply and accurately express their understanding.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Determining the meaning of figurative language provides an extra layer of challenge for English language learners deciphering written content. In order to further engage students in pushing past these challenges to master figurative language, teachers can utilize reading passages and materials that capitalize on [[ Personal-Interest Problems | students' interests ]]. For example, when providing students with sentences containing figurative language, teachers can incorporate the student’s friends, favorite pastimes and life events in the sentences themselves. As figurative language can often seem foreign to middle school students, incorporating personal interest can be an effective strategy to make the learning more relevant.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 7.2 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Optimize relevance, value, and authenticity

goal_text:
By (date), after participating in a read aloud of a "boring story," (e.g. [[ https://docs.google.com/a/goalbookapp.com/document/d/1N8_oxMWb5O-PjCEGnuR7piFolKSkYnK-HoJb4TtNxVQ/edit?usp=sharing | "Saturday Morning" or "Babysitting"]] ), discussing with the class what makes it boring, and brainstorming ways to make it more interesting, (student) will, with a partner, rewrite a second story by taking turns to expand each sentence into (3-4) additional sentences by adding details without moving the action forward, using (2-4) adverbs and (3-5) prepositional phrases. Partners will read the newly expanded story aloud in the correct order and compare it to the original.

EXAMPLES OF WAYS TO MAKE WRITING MORE INTERESTING:
PREPOSITIONAL PHRASES:
Time:                   during the night
                            before the sunrise
                            after the argument

Place/Position:    under the bed
                             on the pillows
                             behind the television

Direction:             toward the door
                             from the couch
                             to the backyard

ADVERBS:           
                            accidentally, awkwardly, beautifully, bravely, calmly, carefully, carelessly, cheerfully, eagerly,  
                            enthusiastically, fiercely, gently, gracefully, greedily, hungrily, innocently, kindly, lazily, mysteriously,  
                            politely, quickly, quietly, rudely, sadly, shyly, silently, sleepily, suspiciously, unexpectedly

Students will read the newly expanded story aloud in the correct order and compare it to the original.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after participating in a read aloud of a "boring story," (e.g. [[ https://docs.google.com/a/goalbookapp.com/document/d/1N8_oxMWb5O-PjCEGnuR7piFolKSkYnK-HoJb4TtNxVQ/edit?usp=sharing | "Saturday Morning" or "Babysitting"]] ), discussing with the class what makes it boring, and brainstorming ways to make it more interesting, (name) will, with a group of (4-6) other students, rewrite a second story, each student expanding one sentence into (2-3) additional sentences by adding details without moving the action forward using (2) descriptive adverbs and (1) prepositional phrase. subject: English Learners
title: Expanding Sentences with Detail
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: Giving students existing sentences as a starting point for expansion, rather than having them generate detailed sentences from scratch allows them to process information in smaller chunks and scaffolds success.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 3.3 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Guide information processing, visualization, and manipulation
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text: Differentiating expectations for English Learners at varying levels of fluency (e.g. advanced students add several prepositional phrases while beginning students add just one or two) allows all students to successfully complete the assignment at a level that is challenging, but not frustrating.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.3 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Build fluencies with graduated levels of support for practice and performance
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Having students work in small groups where each contributes a piece of the project encourages collaborative cooperation and provides support for sustained engagement.

goal_text: By (date), after a peer orally shares (3-5) steps in a sequence of transformations (e.g. 90° clockwise rotation, translate 3 right and 2 down, reflect along the x-axis) and (name) is given [[ Graph Paper | graph paper ]] and [[ Math Manipulatives | models of figures ]] (e.g. tangrams, foam letters), (name) will demonstrate the multiple steps by manipulating the figures along the graph paper for (4 out of 5) transformation exercises.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after a peer orally shares (3-5) transformations (e.g.  90° clockwise rotation, translate 3 right and 2 down, reflect along the x-axis) and given [[ Graph Paper | graph paper ]], [[ Math Manipulatives | models of figures ]] (e.g. tangrams, foam letters) and a [[ Reference Materials | visual cheat sheet ]] illustrating transformations, (name) will work with a [[ peer tutoring | partner ]], taking turns as lead and support problem solver, to demonstrate the multiple steps by manipulating the figures along the graph paper for (4 out of 5) transformation exercises.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after a peer orally shares a simple oral command describing a single transformation (e.g. rotate the figure clockwise, translate the figure to the right) and given [[ Math Manipulatives | models of figures ]] (e.g. tangrams, foam letters) and a [[ Reference Materials | visual cheat sheet ]] illustrating transformations, (name) will work with a [[ peer tutoring | partner ]], taking turns as lead and support problem solver, to adjust the models to correctly demonstrate the transformation (4 out of 5) times.
subject: English Learners
title: Using Listening Skills to Transform Figures
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_text: As the concept of transformation involves the movement of figures, teachers may wish to utilize [[ Animation | animation ]] to visually explain the concept. Many high quality resources exist (e.g.  [[ http://nlvm.usu.edu/en/nav/topic_t_3.html | nlvm.usu.edu ]]). Given all of the domain-specific terminology, learning new mathematical concepts can prove challenging for English language learners. Animations can be an effective method for helping students push past such challenges.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_0_udl_st: UDL I 2.5 Provide Multiple Means of Representation: Illustrate through multiple media
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_text:
As an alternative to using physical models to demonstrate transformations, teachers can provide students with the option of adjusting figures using [[ Illustration | interactive web tools ]]. There are many resources online
 (e.g. [[ http://www.mathsisfun.com/geometry/transformations.html | mathisfun ]],   [[ http://www.mathplayground.com/TransformationWorkshop/Workshop.html | mathplayground ]] ) that allow students to perform transformations in a simple and engaging manner. Technology offers English language learners an avenue for demonstrating work in a manner that is often engaging, non-threatening and highly visual.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_1_udl_st: UDL II 5.1 Provide Multiple Means of Action and Expression: Use multiple media for communication
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_text: Demonstrating transformations for the teacher may prove intimidating for some students. Furthermore, those students that are developing English language proficiency may struggle to communicate effectively with the instructor when it comes to asking for clarification or interpreting guidance and feedback. In some cases, teachers may wish to offer students the support of a [[ Peer Tutoring | peer tutor ]] that is also an English language learner and shares the native language of the student. A peer tutor can serve as an added support, and a model of success.
udl_adaptations_udl_adaptations_2_udl_st: UDL III 8.3 Provide Multiple Means of Engagement: Foster collaboration and communication

goal_text: By (date), after listening to a grade level story, when asked to describe a central character from the story, (name) will verbally state at least (3) inferred traits of that character, and explicitly describe the situation from the story in which the traits were inferred (e.g. "Clifford is easily angered because he yelled at the cashier when she made a small mistake.") in (3 out of 4) stories.
objectives_objective_0_text: By (date), after listening to a grade level story with [[visual aids | visual aids]] of central characters in the story, when asked to describe a central character, (name) will verbally state at least (3) explicit or inferred traits of that character and explicitly describe the situation from the story in which the traits were derived in (3 out of 4) stories.
objectives_objective_1_text: By (date), after listening to an instructional level story with [[visual aids | visual aids]] of central characters in the story, when asked to describe a central character, (name) will verbally state (3) character traits from a teacher provided [[glossary | glossary]], and when prompted, re-enact situations from the story where the character shows those traits (e.g.  A student points to the word "sleepy" in the glossary and says, "Jorge is sleepy."  The teacher asks, "What does Jorge do in the story?"  The student puts her head down on the desk to re-enact what Jorge does in the story.) in (3 out of 4) stories.
subject: English Learners
title: Infer Character Traits from an Oral Story
